conclusion: The problem involves determining how the shadows (A, B, C, and D) of four objects change in position and size when the light source moves to the back-right.
The image shows four objects: an apple (A), a flag (B), a glass sphere (C), and a drumstick (D), each casting a shadow on the ground.
The apple casts a circular shadow (A), the flag casts a rectangular shadow (B), the glass sphere casts an elongated shadow (C), and the drumstick casts an oval shadow (D).
When the light source moves to the back-right, every shadow will move forward-left because shadows are cast in the opposite direction of the light source.
The horizontal distance between the light source and the objects increases, causing all shadows to lengthen slightly.
The apple's shadow (A) moves forward-left and becomes longer/slightly larger due to the new light source position.
The flag's shadow (B) moves forward-left, skews to the left, and becomes a little larger.
The glass sphere's shadow (C) swings forward-left, becomes noticeably longer, and thinner due to its transparency and the light source's new position.
The drumstick's shadow (D) slides forward-left, stretches, and appears a little larger.
Relative enlargement of shadows is more obvious for taller objects (apple, flag) and transparent objects (glass sphere), while the drumstick's shadow gains length but stays roughly the same width.
